title: What will be the end-of-day closing value for the dollar against the renminbi on 30 September 2016?
preds: I think currency questions should always end on a Friday evening when currency markets shut. Is this coincidence this time or planned?

Over the last thirty days, lowest rate has been 6.6625 on 7 Sep, highest 6.6850 on 9 Sep. With only three days left to closing, it will almost certainly remain in the 6.60-6.79 range (though one can never be sure with currencies and commodities!)

WOW.  Finally, and it didn't come from the Chair: Bullard talks the dollar down:
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fed-bullard-idUSKCN0Z315J "The U.S. economy may only need one rate hike for as long as 2-1/2 years and the Federal Reserve is eroding its credibility by indicating otherwise, St. Louis Fed President James Bullard said on Friday in arguing for an overhaul of how the central bank views and discusses policy." "The Fed's actual pace of rate increases has been much slower than what was mapped out by the committee in the past. This mismatch between what we are saying and what we are doing is arguably causing distortions in global financial markets, causing unnecessary confusion over future Fed policy, and eroding credibility of the (Federal Open Market Committee)," he said.
Fed rate decision vs Brexit fears.  Waiting on Brexit news.

China faces various challenges but the key driver or renminbi weakness  is the reliance on credit growth at unsustainable levels and the associated risks. CNY remains a managed currency but all such currencies come with jump risk. Although a stronger renminbi would be broadly beneficial to the transition from investment to consumption, this is currently a secondary objective. Significant appreciation from here is hard to see although it would not be out of character for the authorities to attempt to penalise the crowded shorts and create an impression of being in full control. That aside, a gradual depreciation is the most likely scenario in the near term. A major controlled one-off depreciation to try to put the issue in the past is possible (although it would require a trigger), while an uncontrolled breakdown is less likely in the near term. From 6.60 to 6.80 is not a major move for a free-floating currency but it would be a major move for CNY. NB the question refers to CNY (as per bloomberg link), not CNH.

Update based on yesterday's incremental move above the threshold of 6.60. With more than 3 months left to go, I see this heading further upward, but probably not breaking through 6.80 in that time frame. Moving above 6.80 will lead to breakaway kind of trend which will be unpredictable for global markets.

Just hit 6.6. Upward trend suggests that it'll be above soon. The question is will it stay above or drop down.

I'm making a small adjustment downward on the probability of the RMB reaching the 6.6 to 6.8 range.  It's close, but just below 6.6, and has been moving in that direction (i.e., down vis a vis the dollar).  But the Fed has had to back off of comments about raising interest rates, ... again.  The dollar looks set to either weaken of remain in a narrow range.  I'm still significantly above the consensus that the 6.6 to 6.8 range will be reached, just less sure than before.

Currency markets in the short-term are driven more by expectations than fundamentals. Longer-term the key drivers of exchange rates are differentials in inflation, productivity and interest rates.   Current expectations are for the CNY/$ to continue to weaken.  While there is uncertainity around the timing of a raise in the US overnight rate, there is concensus that the next movement in rates is higher, rather than lower.  Fed Funds futures indicate there is a lower likelihood of US rates rising in June. In contrast, there is no evidence that the Central Bank in China will raise rates any time soon; if any action were to occur, it would likely be stimulative.  China growth has slowed significantly in years and there is considerable excess capacity in their major industries. A further issue is that China is managing its currency not just to the USD, but to a basket of currencies.  The JPY has appreciated significantly since the introduction of negative interest rates and it is likely the Japanese government/BoJ will take steps to bring about a devaluation in the JPY.  This will put pressure on the CNY, likely leading to further depreciation of the CNY versus the USD.

Major adjustment. Was betting more than 50% on it going >6.60 till now. Am now changing tack and betting that it will stay <6.60 since that has been the floor for over 5 years now. Once it breaks >6.60, breaking >6.80 has 50% probability, since markets have a runaway effect on these kind of moves.
I'm thinking that we're not going to see a rate hike from the Fed. So dollar will not be stronger.

My theory: China realizes that record growth rates are a thing of the past and has to adjust to a “new normal” of slower economic growth. China realizes that it cannot continue to prop up the renminbi.  China’s reserves were estimated at 4t in June 2014, and by April 2016 were down to 3.22t(1).  So over the course of those 25 months China spent 780b to prop up the renminbi, which equals 31.2b per month.   At that rate, China only has enough reserves to cover 128 months or 10 years.  Now although 10 years is a long time, it’s not in international finance. By pegging for so long, China was able to achieve “artificial” valuation growth.  This growth turned into confidence, which turned into rosy projections, which turned into debt…  On the contrary, China has built a nice foreign reserve…  Growing up is easy, maturing is not and right now China has some serious maturing to do. In order to simultaneously deal with internal debt issues and curtail the depletion of foreign reserves China will have to allow the renminbi to depreciate (of course China will tightly control such movements).  A slow, controlled devaluation of the renminbi, along with internal structural changes (such as better banking regulations) are really the only chances for stability and long-term prosperity. I don't see any other way forward that makes sense. Furthermore, if China wants to be taken seriously as a Special Drawing Rights Currency, it really has to allow the renminbi to freely(2) depreciate.   (1) http://www.wsj.com/articles/china-preferring-stability-to-free-markets-loses-resolve-to-revamp-currency-1464022378
(2) The definition of freely in this sense is quite subjective...

There seems to be a strong consensus on 6.4-6.6 and some of the reasoning offered is quite good. However, I also feel (strongly) that Chinese central bank is slowly working towards a soft landing of the economy, and I think the currency devaluation will be a soft one. I think a devaluation to 7.0000 this year should go some way to capture the internal problems of the debt mountain that the country has well enough ($1.7tn). Furthermore, currency will devalue further in the coming year, I reckon. If 7.0000 has to happen by end of this year, roughly in 8 months, won't be straight line but still, I reach a level of close to 6.8 by end -Sep. I might be a little aggressive by saying 7.0000, so I will probably give slightly above majority to my 6.6-6.8 range answer to indicate my primary thought process here, which I would like to revise as we move ahead. 6.8+ is a daring answer, but one I believe has a higher likelihood than under 6.6 put together - also, given that in my logic, 6.8 could be a very high probability focal point, I would give due consideration to this thought - hence giving half the probability of 6.6-6.8 range. The remaining, I will distribute as 2/3rd to 6.4-6.6, since I think between the remaining two ranges, this one is twice as likely as under 6.4.

6.5101 Fading odds for a June rate hike, and slowing GDP growth would argue for US$ depreciation vs Renminbi. However, under the new provisions of the 205 Trade Facilitation and Enforcement Act, the U.S. Treasury placed China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Germany on a monitoring list for reporting to Congress.  The FT reports the criterion for inclusion are meeting 2 out of three of the following: 1) bilateral trade deficit > $20b against the U.S., 2) Current account deficit > 3% of GDP, 3) FX intervention > 2% of GDP over 1 year. Even though the Renminbi is generally considered to be overvalued, the Act may or may not influence Chinese policy, which recently has been targeting stabilization against a basket of currencies.

Weak growth and low inflation in the US may prevent the Fed from raising interest rates more than one more time in 2016.  This will prevent the dollar from surging, which puts pressure on the RMB.  The CCP wants a stable exchange rate, and has tools to keep the currency stable.  They can achieve their goal if the Fed doesn't do much in the way of higher interest rates this year.  With 5 months to go, stability of the exchange rate seems to be the best bet.

There is a 9 year lag between PPP and Market Exchange Rates, as per the literature and previous historical experience. In the long run,PPP and MER become equal. As per the Big Mac Index Zhongguo January 2016 Price: $2.68 (Yuan 17.60)
Raw index: undervalued by 45.6%
Actual exchange rate: 6.56
Implied exchange rate*: 3.57
http://www.economist.com/content/big-mac-index World Price Index finds 20% undervaluation.
http://www.worldeconomics.com/WorldPriceIndex/WPI.efp "Over the longer term exchange rates are “anchored” by price levels.  This idea is embodied in  purchasing  power  parity  (PPP)  theory,  which  states  that  the  exchange  rate  is  proportional  to  the ratio  of  price  levels  in  the  two  countries.  To  illustrate,  Figure  1.1  uses  annual  data  to  plot  the  exchange  rate  (relative  to  the  US  dollar)  of  the  United  Kingdom  and  Japan  and  the  ratio  of  their price  level  to  that  of  the  US.    British  prices  increased  relative  to  those  in  the  US  over  the  past  30 years,  while  those  of  Japan  decreased.    According  to  PPP  theory,  the  British  pound  should  have depreciated  (an  increase  in  the  pound  cost  of  the  dollar),  and  the  Japanese  yen  should  have appreciated.    This  is  what  in  fact  happened.    Even though  at  times  the  exchange  rate  deviates substantially  from  the  price  ratio,  there  is  a  distinct  tendency  for  this  ratio  to  play  the  role  of  the underlying trend, or anchor, for the exchange rate.   That is to say, while the exchange rate meanders around  the  price  ratio,  over  time  it  has  a  tendency to  revert  to  this  trend  value,  so  the  ratio  can  be thought  of  as  the  “underlying  value”  of  the  currency.    Figure  1.1  thus  provides  some prima  facie evidence in favour of PPP over the long term" Another argument based on prior history of exchange rates, Exchange rates went from 8.19 in 2005 to 6.2 in 2015. A 32% appreciation. Unless the CCP has gone crazy, a 45.6% appreciation is not possible. 20% seems much more likely. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_%28nominal%29

RMB is currently at 6.47/USD (Apr 15th). HIstorically it has appreciated over USD by about 2%/year in the last 10 years.
This effect, without external shocks, would bring the currency at about 6.40 by end of September. Thus:
1) <6.4 is 50% due to the "natural" appreciation of the RMB and uncertainty surrounding US economy, also considering the presidential elections still ongoing
2) <6.6 is 40% slightly less likely than 6.4 since the window is much smaller
3) <6.8 is 9% considering the possibility of bad economic news for China or another market crash (assessed at 10%, 9% within the 6.8 range and 1% beyond)
IMF predicting China growth forcast is improving.

Based on current option pricing for the CME Aug 2016 CNY/USD futures contracts. 
http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/fx/emerging-market/chinese-renminbi_quotes_globex_options.html?optionExpiration=Q6#strikeRange=ALL A put at .156 costs .00293, for implied volatility of around 3% and about 15.5% chance of being in the money at contract end. 6.4 = .15625 A call at .151 costs .00238 for implied volatility of a little under 2% and a ~10% chance of being in the money at contract end. A call at .147 costs .00619 for a ~0% chance of being in the money at contract end. The lopsidedness reflects my own views - that the Chinese government is not going to devalue and will actively try to prevent devaluation as it has done in recent months. Also the Fed is not going to hike any time soon.

After looking at a couple of other major currency relationships for China I am revising some of my forecasts.  For the past nine months, the depreciation of the Yuan to the Euro, to the Yen, and the US$ are right about the same now (let's call it 5%).  My guess is that they would call that a success.  Yes, bumpy and a few bungles but what they were hoping for and now the capital flight feels more under control.  Another 2-3% depreciation is very possible and desired.  Also, tilting my forecast is that I think recent US$ weakness will fade over the next few months.

The Chinese government seems to have decided to let the Yuan fall vs. the US$. One argument says: let it fall to help imports. The other says: keep it steady or US$ debt is painful to repay, and capital flight will continue. I think conventional economists still feel more sympathy for the first argument. Also, the perceived benefits of the first argument are more short term. So, on balance, I think the Chinese will continue the fall. On the other side, the Feds are hesitant to raise rates, but are still making noises about doing so. If the U.S. employment rate stays low and GDP stays steady, they may decide to go "one more and done" before the elections.

Although the CNY was recently added to the IMF's SDR, it is still functionally a managed float that the central government wants to keep tight control over. Volatility has picked up quite a bit since January 2014, however we can see that the currency is still tightly controlled. After a relatively rapid appreciation of 0.47% per month against the US Dollar, the CNY appreciated at a much slower pace from May 2010 to January 2014, at about 0.27% per month. What's most interesting to me is that since the CNY began depreciating in January of 2014, the pace of depreciation has been almost exactly the same 0.27% per month. It is quite likely that the Chinese government is comfortable with this pace of depreciation and are very likely to stick to it despite what market commentators or other countries might say (as evidenced in their management of the CNY appreciation from 2005 to 2013). Extrapolating out 6.633 months at that same rate gives us an expected value of 6.61 for the CNY at 30 September. The thing that might change the pace of this rate is a more pronounced weakening in the local economy. Over the past couple of years the CNY has actually appreciated significantly against many of its trading partners as emerging market and developed Asia currencies as well as the EUR have sold off against the Dollar between 15 and 35%. Volatility in global markets may also hasten the depreciation if the Dollar continues to strengthen. My expected value for the CNY is right at the 6.6 break point, however, it appears that the forces favoring a more rapid depreciation are prevailing. A depreciation past 6.8 seems unlikely, as that would mean an almost 5% move. With the way the 3% adjustment in August impacted markets, the Chinese government will probably not want to use that option unless the situation is particularly dire.

It's kind of funny, but I find the consensus estimates (medians) on these semi-esoteric / low participation questions to be much more compelling than the qns with tons of participation (i.e. US election qns).  To me, consensus on this looks pretty good (right now: 5/30/44/21).  I wound up slightly overweight the two >$6.60 options at the expense of the $6.40-6.60 option.   Factors/Thoughts: 1) The forward curve (@6.62 in september): http://www.cmegroup.com/europe/products/fx/emerging-markets/usd-cny.html  (h/t @voxvox who also cited this) 2) Kyle Bass comments on yuan devaluation thesis: http://www.zerohedge.com/news/2016-02-10/fasten-your-seatbelts-kyle-bass-previews-collapse-chinas-34-trillion-banking-sector 3)  Ray Dalio thoughts on Yuan / China: 
http://www.businessinsider.com/dalio-china-is-having-a-heart-transplant-2016-3 4) Generally, my opinion is that China often seems like a mess to me, but Chinese policy makers have a lot of tools and with only a couple exceptions I can think of, seem to implement them fairly successfully.  I think overall the path we're on is a devaluation path and that is more or less clear.  Whether that happens slowly or quickly, I really do not know. 5)  Biggest risk: USD has strengthened a lot vs. yuan (and most currencies) over the last couple yrs: http://www.xe.com/currencycharts/?from=USD&to=CNY&view=5Y .  Right now, the USD is pricing in growth/strength and a likely 2nd rate rise from Fed.  If China holds it together and situation in US deteriorates, would be easy to see this move the wrong way. I have looked over the chart over the previous few years, and a jump to over 6.8 in this time frame would be a HUGE devaluation, virtually a crash in value, during this time-frame.  This could happen if the Chinese government reset the peg or stopped defending the value of the renminbi.  But barring that, such a move seems highly improbable.  Especially because China is still sitting on a gigantic pool of foreign currency reserves.  Yes, they have gone through about $600 billion in the previous six months, but they have about 3.2 trillion to go.  It would seem to be in their interest to allow very gradual devaluation, and their reserves would easily allow such an outcome for the next several months.   I suppose its worth mentioning that it seems highly improbable to me that we will see an appreciation trend resulting in the renminbi going under 6.4 during the next six months.  All the market and economic forces are currently pushing the other direction.

CNY is sitting at 6.5 today. A move to 6.8 would imply around a 4-5% difference from where it is currently trading. That doesn't sound like much, but it would be a far steeper rate of change than the dramatic graph of the past year, which in turn is by far the most rapid change in valuation of the CNY since the peg was removed. I think we'll get there eventually, but my gut tells me not before September 30th. * Take a look at the graph here [1], and turn the range up to "all". CNY has undergone vast changes in valuation over the past 15 years, but it typically happens over a longer time-frame. [1] http://www.google.com/finance?q=USDCNY&ei=bTXfVvGZB4e32AaGu7uoAg
